Tons of eatery littered along the whole stretch of street. Popular ones are the beef shops, dozens of these shops as you walk down the street.
Great place to visit in the heart of downtown. Has its own little vibe here and transportation abounds.
We wondered into this area looking for coffee and after 5 minutes we vacated the area. The mainlanders turned this quiet place into a 'fish market'.

A convenient stop where the complimentary shuttles drop off and pick up point was from the cruise terminal. One of the cleaner Chinatown with colorful buildings and shops. We did not buy or eat there but enjoyed the festive atmosphere with many visitors from all over the world.
Located in downtown Kobe, very vibrant lunch time experience. Tons of food fresh prepared and lively. Some shopping too. Smiling locals.

Come here if you want some chinese food, the vendors here stand infront and promote their restaurant, they have many dish to select for, good for street food and dine in, find long queue and you know its good food there

Went there to experience the Chinatown street. A lot of street food and restaurants. The grocery shop have a good spread of Chinese ingredients you can get from there . Even the Taiwan ingredients, you can get. Bubble tea are also mushrooming around this area . Take the
Not my best experience with 'china town' settings, by far. All places copy each other in terms of food. We had a duck roll and were not impressed and decided to go elsewhere for actual lunch.
A good place to visit. Lots of glittering light and lots of people in a good mood. It is also in a good position and acceptable from the metro.

They call it Chinatown. What they sell on display are almost the same everywhere. Pork bun, duck, dumplings, etc. Prices are quite expensive given the portion size and choices. Spent about 1000yen ++ and to be honest, nothing special. Buildings are quite bright and colorful
Nice place to walk around. Even the tourist-trap-type restaurants with people outside beckoning you in are charming.
Nothing much, some chinese noodles and dishes, lotsa shops selling dumplings. LOL. Feels like the only chinese thing is dumplings and nothing else. Stroll for 10mins and left.

One of the great historic places as a result Japan opening up to the world. Kobe chinatown is not huge but it packs a lot in. During the day, the street is lined with so many different food stalls to choose from. There is are pork belly bao, peeking duck wraps and so many other
Didn’t get to try a lot of the most recommended restaurants/street vendors because they close at 6:30pm on a Sunday... those left open were average but very cheap at least.
But it has shops, so wife had to explore:(, lots of activity though, cafes, bars, restaurants and food is great in all of them

We wandered through mid afternoon thinking we may eat there that evening, decided to try elsewhere. Lots of stalls all seeking basically the same snacks. All a bit samey and disappointing really. The Shanghai dumplings stall off the central square was busy with a fair queue but

It was more a long alleyway with a few street vendors, rather than a true Chinatown that bustles with Chinese restaurants. Maybe still worth a visit on your way to the Kobe Port as it won’t take you long to walk around it.

Nice little area to visit with excellent street foods, and other souvenir type shopping. There are multiple food vendors available. I highly suggest the shaved ice fruit. It was so delicious and refreshing on a hot day!

I walked here from my hotel one afternoon and noticed that many of the vendors had cooked and raw meet offerings outside and uncovered. I couldn’t bring myself to buy any but certainly it’s a place to spend an hour or so wandering. We tried to find a restaurant with a menu

This Chinatown must be one of the least interesting ones across the world. Absolutely nothing to see except displays of plastic-looking dishes set next to empty Tsingtao beer bottles. Even the Disney Corp. and its goons could come up with a more genuine "Chinese" atmosphere.

This Chinatown in Kobe is unashamedly touristy but it's fun to walk through. At night it's especially nice with all the lanterns lit and the neon flashing everywhere. Only the Japanese really know how to use neon! Loads and loads of eateries and souvenir stalls. If you like

Kobe Chinatown or Nankin-Machi is one of the three Chinatown areas in Japan besides Nagasaki and Yokohama as Japan's largest chinatown.The location is in front of Daimaru Departmen Store and not far from Kobe Port Tower,just a three block walk to get to the port of Kobe. So

One of the most beautiful China town you could find, very clean, well decorated and foods is everywhere you look, either a snack or sit down proper meal. If you are visiting Kobe for their Kobe beef, highly recommend you swing by as well.

Located near the Sannomiya Station area, this small Chinatown consists of a few main streets and is also very close to a shopping street/arcade. You will find many Chinese street food stalls, boba teas/drinks & even Kobe Beef restaurants (signs advertised very cheap prices, so

Nice place to visit. Enjoy one of the famous pan fried dumpling there. But. Make sure if you want to try the 和🐂牛 better look for one can trust . My suggest not to go this shop waste money. Warning. Don’t go to this lousy Kobe beef restaurant even he keep saying sorry sorry
Good thing is you can get here by the Kobe loop bus. But there is nothing much to see here, just a long row of eateries and stalls selling similar food.

One of the stops on the City Loop Bus. Personally disappointing. Just one lane with some side tracks of Chinese restaurants and outside street food sellers. Prices questionable and aimed more at tourist wallets than locals. If you need a Chinese fix, go to China, it's as
If you need a bit of Chinese street food in Kobe, this is the place. Mostly food stalls but some stores as well.

Loaded with Chinese shops and restaurants, with some of the latter also offering Japan’s famous Kobe beef. Also typical of a Chinatown, there are lots of street food, and of a high quality. This is one of the world’s more exciting Chinatowns.
This is another popular tourist attraction in Kobe. Even better if you are hungry as there are many restaurants selling all sorts of Chinese food.
A large area with sit down restaurants and food stalls. Lots to choose from. China theme stores. Fun area to visit.

Its sort of the commercial hub of this laid back town. So one can start at one end and keep on walking while browsing through the titbits to buy. And there are some decent restaurants too. The square has a nice charm in the evening!

Lots of restaurants, good food and some what cheap (compare to other similar places in Kobe). There are several souvenir stores that sells some Chinese/Japanese items. The center square has little statures of the 12 Chinese Zodiacs, good place to take some cute pictures. Nice
One of cleanest China town experience. They all seem to sell same kinds of Chinese foods on each food stall. All good. Must visit
Nice place to spent a couple of hours enjoying the street food. But avoid the “Kobe beef” in the middle of the junction. It’s rip-off (photo).
Everything you need and a lot you don't need can be found here. You could spend days just roaming around the market.
So many delicious food to eat and it is a great place to just walk around while snacking. So many cute and unique shops too
Although it is small China town area, It is really clean and Nice place. It is good for Chinese delicious food where we can enjoy different type of Chinese food.
We wandered through looking for a meal, had dinner wanted to retuyfor a snack after but by 8pm most places were closing or already closed.
Chinatown goes down one main street. Very vibrate and colourful. Lots wonderful street food and characters.

Called one of the three biggest China Town in Japan, but smaller than that of Yokohama only with one main street along. The street has many shops, mainly restaurants or stalls.Access is OK, as Motomachi Station of JR and Hanshin can be available. Sannomiya Station is also
We mostly just walked around and tooled at everything. Chinese food in Japan is very good! It was crowded even in February.

This was ok to pass some time and I might have liked it better if I had not already spent 10 days in China. Had some great Kobe beef, but overall I found this place a bit overrated. Might be good if in Japan and not getting a chance to go to China... We did as a way of
One of the few Chinatowns in Japan. Reasonable variety of shops and lot of food stalls, Chinese food with a slight Japanese bent (Peking duck at a food stall?). Worth a quick visit.
Plenty of people just busy busy, few minutes from sogo and JR Kobe station. If shopping and eating is your thing then it’s worthwhile going.
Check out this Chinatown at Kobe, the streets are narrow yet busy... Come hungry and work your way through the food stalls, variety of tasty and affordable Chinese cuisine that will make you drool!

If you have been to China Towns in New York or elswhere forget about this one! – First of all it is very small - just a fews streets. Second it looks more like a China Town Theme Park, nothing authentic! Just a lot of Japanes Teenagers that enjoy somehting like Chinese-Japanes

Having visited many Chinatowns around the world, this one is less impressive than most of the others. When compared to the one in Yokohama the Kobe Chinatown is really tiny and basically consists of one long street with a square in the middle. Mostly there are restaurants with

If you happen to be in Kobe, it's a good stopover just to get some interesting eats. Don't expect much cause it's a really small area, so don't purposely make a trip there unless you already are in Kobe and are looking for something decent to do while in Kobe.

I visit China town in Kobe every time I am in Kobe. It is a busy and exciting place, a kind of mini-China. A lot of food stands are selling snacks for eating while walking around. It is maybe not the most delicious food, but it is a fun place to visit.

A small area with Chines souvenirs och food. Decorated with Chinese lamps, went there during daylight , returned in evening but that was a disapointment, the decorating lamps where not lightning the place up.

I was in Kobe on the evening of mid-November. I wanted to have dinner at Kobe's Chinatown, so I went there. I thought it was bigger but it's quite small. I saw pictures of it full of people, but when I was there, I saw almost no one, and it was 7-8pm. It was a bit deserted, I
Lots of restaurants, and quaint and interesting alleys and shops as well. Lots of fusions Chinese, Japanese and some European

Compared to the one in Yokohama, this is a small Chinatown: looked like few streets. When you alight at the JR Motomachi station and walk towards Meriken park you will cross China Town with lots of eateries. You will find tourists hanging around. There are gates at roads leading
Quite a small Chinatown but good enough with many Chinese restaurants. Surprise to see many Japanese came to this place for Chinese food.

It's pretty much one street with restaurants and stalls lined on both sides of the street selling the same fare (dumplings, Peking duck, pork buns etc). Hardly anyone around even at dinner time on a Thursday when I visited.
You'll find mainly food, not so many gifts or other items, anyway is a nice place to go and is between other Japanese restaurants and the harbor.

This looked to be a popular market just off the main shopping area, and worth a walk through to look at all the different varieties of foods on offer. Obviously Kobe beef is very popular here, and surprised to see this steak selling at realistic prices in many venues having seen

As with any other Chinatowns elsewhere, the Kobe Chinatown is characterized by narrow alleys, imposing Chinatown gates, vibrant businesses, exotic food selection and overcrowdedness. A good place for a reasonable eat and decent stroll through from the Motomachi Station to the

This isn’t the best china town I have seen and while it’s very clean it is mostly low cost street food with some ordinary restaurants. It’s aimed at tourists and apart from the colourful photos and displays the one meal I had there was very ordinary. Nice for a walk through and

Its easy to get to and there are a lot of shops for options. For me however, I found the experience a waste of time. I was excited to try the Butaman, the dan dan from Yun Yun and dumplings from Ro Sho Ki as I read in blogs. Unfortunately, I found nothing extraordinary here.

Chinatown was cool -great for street food nibbles. (Make sure you have cash; Japan is a huge cash society and many places don't take cards.) If you have some time, stroll through this part of town and take it all in.

We enjoyed strolling down the main street of Chinatown, looking at all the colorful souvenirs and the great variety of Japanese food displayed. We found a stand offering Kobe beef grilled right there while you watched. For about $15 US we got a small plate of grilled strips
Nice area to spend a couple hours, there are a lot of places to eat, and buy Chinese items. We went just one evening

Quite a small Chinatown compared to the others like in Yokohama but still having enough stalls for one to accept and appreciate that they are in Chinatown. While in Kansai, I do recommend a visit to here

The hype about Chinatown makes me wonder why so. 3 interesting facts that I discovered on Kobe’s Chinatown: (i) It is so small that I can walk from one end to the other end less than 5 mins, (ii) There are numerous food vendors selling identical items, (iii) It is one place in

This is quite a compact area easily reached from a stop on the city sightseeing bus and close to a big shopping mall. There were plenty of street food vendors and typical Chinatown outlets. Not crowded when we visited on a rainy day..

Interesting place, crowded on a week day, lots of people, saw a few food stalls, selling cheap kobe beef, didn't try them, as we weren't sure of the quality. Had a nice, roasted ice cream, not sure how they cook it. Not many variety of item to shop. Will recommend
China town is a nice and vibrant area, lots of character. Plenty of street food some of it mediocre but if you luck in some of it superb. If there is a lineup of locals then try it.

One of the smallest Chinatown I have seen, if you do not stop for street food or dine at one of the numerous restaurants that dotted along the street and the adjacent alleys, you can finish the visit in 10 minutes. It gets very quite after 7:00 PM with only a handful of

Kobe Chinatown or Nankin Machi is fairly small but there are a wide range of shops crammed into the area. It is divided into different Chinese areas such as "Shanghai" or Hong Kong" It appears to be pretty crowded most of the time..Nankin Machi is fairly easy to navigate with

located next to Motomachi shopping street (3-5 mins walk). You can see a lot of street food right outside restaurants. A lot of street food such as Xiao Long Pau, fried chicken, etc (mostly similar for all). Well, you too can eat at restaurants which I saw some queue for

We stopped off here for something to eat as it was a stop on the city loop bus. It’s a small typical china town area with a lot of places to eat. You can easily leave this out and spend more time at the herb gardens or the marina area.

Nankinmachi makes for an interesting experience when visiting Japan. Visit during Chinese New Year and you get a lion dance as part of the experience. Extremely popular with the locals on a weekend, people come for the food, it is mostly food stalls. Add it to your Kobe visit
A bit disappointed with what was on offer. 90% food stalls so there was no reason to stay within the area once you found something to eat.
We returned to Kobe’s port from a tour late and took the port shuttle to Chinatown at7pm most of the shops were closed except the restaurants we enjoyed a good meal

We came here by chance so decided to walk through from one Chinese gate to the other. It had a buzzy feel to it with food stalls and interesting snacks to try. It was bbuzzing with people local and tourist and we really enjoyed people watching. I had a Turkish ice cream from a
Chinatown is a little too touristy. Not sure if food is any good. Fun to walk around just to get a feel of it. I hear it gets lively and busy during Chinese New Year.
We were looking forward to visiting. Every stall sold the same food and the buns were tasteless and the duck wrap were horrible and cold. Someone needs to help these people on the food quality.
Interesting to visit but nothing much to buy . Chinese restaurants selling dumpling , duck and pork but nothing outstanding Very small as it only spread over few alley way

This is the first Chinatown I've been to in Japan and I was surprised with all the traditional chinese products and food they were selling. There are lots of restaurants, food stalls and places that sell traditional chinese crockery too.

Soo crowded on Chinese New Year-which I expect. Love the food, get to see the "barongsai"-lion dance and artist singing. The place is non smoking all over Kobe but there are some restaurants that allow smoking. Worth the trip for CNY.
It's quite clean and nice. But to me, it's just like other China Towns in Japan. However, if you have free time, it's good to have a look & walk around.

Disappointed to go and walked around Chinatown in Kobe. Seeing much bigger ones in Yokohama, Japan or other parts of world. If you have not been any China town before, you may get some idea but not really impressed one in Kobe.

Having lived in San Francisco....and really missing good Chinese food.....I was really disappointed with my food experience here. I went to one restaurant that was recommended by my hotel It was attractive.....the staff was attentive.....but the food left a lot to be desired. It
China men everywhere and china women everywhere. Ideal place if you have not experienced chinese markets before. Food, suvenirs, whatever chinese make etc etc
We enjoyed our walks in Chinatown. We met a lot of japanese tourists. The storeowners we noth extremely helpful and nice. We had some great food, and did a lot of shopping there.
As with other reviews, it is not overly large and some places are overpriced. However, try the bakery on the south side of the main street. Absolutely superb cakes.

It's the famous Chinatown street in Kobe. There are many shops and restaurant selling Chinese food. It doesn't worth the long queue as you can find many nice Chinese restaurants in kobe. The visit was not that enjoyable as we couldn't really walk as it was very crowded on

It didnt seem any different from the usual cookie cutter Chinatowns. Lotsa of food joints but we found the food too oily and there was also "mystery meat" that looked way too dark (old?)in one or two places. We opted to eat elsewhere. Food was so so.

Are you Chinese? If so, this is no great place for Chinese who would have been to better and larger Chinatown in your home country. It is a very small area and if you are not stopping to eat, you can stroll pass in less than 20 minutes.

Don’t expect the Chinatown in Kobe to impress. It’s a single street that goes for about 2 blocks or so, and is tailored to the Japanese palate. We enjoyed the street food, but it cannot compare to Taiwan or Hong Kong, naturally. If you don’t have high expectations, it’s a fun
This is the right place if you feel like Chinese food. Price is very accessible, but all the shops food looks the same. Experience was ok if you miss Chinese food, because this is not authentic.

Small part of Kobe, but with really nice food. Lots of stalls outside, but also many small restaurants, busy and a good ambience. Culture wise nothing, but a very welcoming change from the Japanese cuisine.

Just one street but very colorful and with lots of options for snacks and eat. We walk also through the tiny streets that flows from the main where you also can find nice restaurants. Try some of the street food like the bao bread or the skewers
Chinese street food of Japanese quality. It’s the Perfect food for a cold winters day. Can’t go wrong here!

This area is basically selling many chinese food and snacks with some japanese twists. You can either queue and eat at one of the eateries of you can buy the one at the roadside and eat it. Make sure you bring a trash bag with you because very few rubbish bins. The food are just

A lot of stalls selling Jap and Chinese food. Many youngsters and tourists. Be prepared to eat here else not much things to do. A few small boutiques selling winter clothing. There is a Daimaru mall opposite it.

A small Chinatown area that is really only one main street and a small square. There are doze4ns of food stalls that are continually trying to get you to buy - I soon learned the Japanese for 'no thank you' which went down well with the locals. A fun place but not somewhere i'd

I was in Kobe for a day sightseeing with my wife. We took the Nanshin train from Namba to Osaka. The Chinatown is not far from the Sannomiya station but we only came to the Chinatown after exploring the northern area so by the time we reached Nankinmachi it was already late
Went at around 6pm on a weekday and it was really small and quiet. There seems to be a queue for a popular meat bun. There are many restaurants but it was quite disappointing.

A small area in Kobe about 10 minutes away from Sannomiya station. It’s not the best Chinatown but it’ll satisfy your hunger for Chinese food especially if you want a break from Japanese food. Stalls upon stalls of siopao, dumplings, duck, and yes, kobe beef. Tip: find a
Great walk, but if you want to try some of the restaurants, come early, Long Qs expected. Come evening as well, 2x as good
A small but a clean and quiet China town. The food is OK but all the restaurants looked more or less the same. The food offerings and the prices was almost the at every restaurant.
If you've ever been to a Chinatown, any Chinatown, then you can skip this one. Lots of eateries, not much else.

Not really special Chinatown. It is purely touristic and nothing authentic. Lots of restaurants of course, but they also are not really special, but just rather expensive, Still, nice to walk through, but that is it.
We visited on sunday. The place was too much crowded even to walk. All the restaurants were full and every restaurants' staffs were pulling to their shop...Foods aere not so impressive...
The décor of this Chinatown was not the worst. The street were not too dirty. The restaurants in there were quite modern too. It worth to have a look if you were around.

There are Chinatowns in all over the world. Japan is no exception. There are three Chinatowns in Japan. The Chinatown in KOBE city is called Nankin-machi. There are a lot of chinese food restaurants and we can have them inside and outside of the restaurants. Most of the
Just like every China Town around the world, this area is very crowded, food is not as good as in China. But for non-Chinese, it might be an interesting place.
The port area was very interesting with its history and lots of modern shops. China Town for lots of lovely fresh cooked food.

Kobe's Chinatown is a compact area of a few blocks. Those few blocks are crazy busy. There are shops selling all kinds of cheap items, restaurants and street food to suit all tastes - as long as your taste is for Chinese. Noisy, colourful, crowded.

The china town covered a large area, with many roads lined with all the snacks you could think of. You get a great feeling of warmth whilst wondering the streets. It restaurants where to numerous to mention. They were of course there to the cater for Chinese and visitors from
You can get anything Chinese here. From early morning rice porridges to fine dining dinners from cheap to very expensive.
A great way to get your Chinese food fill with heaps of restaurants and little stalls all the way down the street. Lots of alley ways to enjoy all around the area.

I have been here for three or four times with my friends. Actually it was my first Chinese town I have been to, so I don't really have any thing to compare. The street was quite nice at night with red lanterns, but there was not many things to see. The street food is all the

Lots of interesting shops, restaurants and sculptures. I enjoyed the one that showed the animals of the Chinese zodiac. Some street stalls served Kobe beef. It was quite good and I heard this option is not bad and much less than the price you would pay for at a restaurant.

We went in the day time but was still buzzing duribg the day. There are so many tourists there and so many food stalls. You must try the Kobe Beef it is delicious. I loved it. There are other chinese stalls with so many different foods there you can try all if you want. It is
We wet into a street food shop to eat. Tried many including the fried duck wrapped...gyozas..etc. All are a bit tasteless. Not hot enough...and overpriced.
The China town in Japan is similar to any China town in major cities in the world. Food is abundant in numerous food stalls but there is a particular store where people line up for the steamed buns.

There were many food carts and shops selling Chinese food. Prices for food were not cheap, as like other food options in Japan. I read in other reviews that the kobe beef sold in this area is relatively cheap due to different cuts and grades of the beef. Indeed, we did come
I think if you would have a cheap lunch in Kobe, it's better go to China town Kobe. 安くて美味しいランチを食べたいならば神戸では南京町に行くべきです。
It's almost like it, but cleaner than in China. Many food stores and restaurants, including Kobe beaf !

We came here on a Saturday afternoon. It was busy with a lot of food carts/restaurants. We tried strawberry & mango snow ice, ramen, Kobe Beef and fried rice. My favorite of the bunch was the mango snow ice which was creamy and delicious! It did take a while to prepare though;

From kobe tower we had a long walk going to china town. You will pass by a long street where theres a lot of local shops. It was sunday so a bit crowded. In chinatown theres a lot of food shops, variety of food and mostly affordable as servings are mid size. Most people are

This place is packed all the time with tourists and locals. We found though if you reach the end the prices tend to be more expensive so if you want to eat something stick to the middle where the food was often cheaper. there are good bargains to be had but you have to cruise or
love going to the different Chinatowns they all have their own little differences but always lots of people lots of food so much to look at dont ever think you can just pop down for half an hour.

It is a bit strange to visit a chinatown in Japan but it is located in the central of Kobe, so we decided to try our chance and we were quite glad in the end. The prices are a bith high than average and it is always crowded, however there are many differents tastes that you can

Not very impressed with the china town itself but the area is quite accessible with other shopping malls and restaurants. This is quite a typical type of china town in Japan. Most stuff are pricey too and always crowded with tourist.

Visited this place multiple times. They do have tasty Chinese food, but all popular spots are way too crowded to enjoy. As always, it's very safe and no problems even at night. The best way to go is to look around, read few reviews and target less crowded places. Awesome

Great experience to see how is an Asian Chinatown. It is probably the most typical I have visited. Lots of amazing little shops, statues and crowded like you expect a true Chinatown to be. Worth the visit!

The are itself is two main streets intersecting each other, in the centre is a large open plaza with a small pagoda. The place is really busy, lots of people around, and there's a great atmosphere with all the streets lined with various food vendors. Most of the shops, seemed

Although a much smaller Chinatown than the one in Yokohama this one is not as expensive and I fancy it contains more stuff you can find in the latter. Good place for some chinese food if you want an alternative to the Japanese fare but then again it is pretty adapted for local

Eating on the street isn't really au fait in Japan, but this is one place that is. I had a piece of the widely feted Kobe beef, which really did melt in the mouth, and a Chinese duck roll which was very nice, but don't eat the paper it's wrapped in like I did. A nice
Just visit as it is very busy with many people and many shops. Great place to soak in the culture and people watch! Reasonable Kobe beef restaurant in the area.
Just another China town really and I am not a fan of Chinese food so this is a biased review. People seem nice and all clean and tidy.
There are plenty of restaurants to choose from. I was there in the evening and it wasnt really very crowded. The alleys offer nice lighting and chinese style rest pit-stops.

This is a great spot to meander for an hour or so, even more if you're hungry or it's nighttime. We were there during the day, so we did not see all the evening magic. There's plenty of food to choose from and souvenir shops selling just about everything...but a lot of

It's a Small chinatown if you compare to chinatown in yokohama. Or...probably the same. Not as big as i thought. But this place is still something that you cannot miss. How to get here? No worries bcause The circular bus stops at the chinatown. Actually this place is in the

This place is best in the day for shopping and at night for eating and viewing all the cool lights ....almost every street vendor has great fresh food and they stay open late past 10pm....worth visiting and close to the train stations enjoy !!!
Many good street foods and small shops. But for me this one is quite small compares to other chinatowns.
the hop on hop off bus gets you there, very easy walk to wander around and take a look. not lot to see mainly food stalls and restaurants.

Chinatown in Kobe is a good place for people Om a limited budget in Kobe to eat inexpensively ,the majority of the street food in Kobe can be found around sannomiya station but this Chinatown is very clean as is the majority of thing in japan
Amazing to see a Chinatown in Japan! The street is lined up with stalls and restaurants that serve some decent Chinese snacks and even cuisines.
Small short area and didn't look interesting at all. Prices also don't look cheap. Frankly I think we finished walking the street in 15 minutes.
Great place to get some "roadside" food to try and taste , especially for tourist. Kobe beef steak is sold there. nice though expensive But do not try the kobe beef burger, disgusting and bad taste.

Kobe Chinatown is comparably small. This is an old part of town. Walking through the main area .... there are lots food stalls on both sides of the way. Traditional Chinese lanterns beautifully lighted up this place. There were a number of small and medium sized restaurants

Take the JR train from Sanomiya Station to Motomachi Station and head south; Nankinmachi is about 250 meters away. The collection of eating outlets serving Chinese and Japanese cuisines, the various others selling small bites that you can take with you as you walk along

There is really nothing special about this place. A short street with some Chinese restaurants. Nothing much that I can talk about. Located about 3 minutes walk from the train station, if you happened to pass-by, intend to take a look, thats fine. No real need to make a

Really characteristic and interesting neighbor in Kobe. One of the only three Chinatown in Japan, and the smallest compared to the one in Yokohama and Nagasaki, but really enjoyable to visit. Recommended.
Many people here. Many choices of Chinese food here. Not cheap and people are willing to Q up to take the food there.

Can't recommend any restaurant or street vendor-but this street/area has plenty of street stalls and restaurants with steamed dumplings,Peking duck wraps and all sorts of other unidentifiable foods ( for a westerner). If you see something that catches your eye-go for it..

It was very crowded on January 2nd. It is more or less like a food street. There are several shops offer a wide varieties of food. It is another attractive place for tourists. We enjoyed walking around, even with a very cold weather .
I expected well orientated Chinese town, but I feel like I am in Japan anyway. I ate Japanese food in Chinese town :D

A great area to visit and have fun. Many, many street vendors so lots of people eating on the street. Peking Duck very popular with everyone eating small packets of this delight whilst walking and taking in the street. Very nice Jazz Bar around the corner too. More of this later!

This place was very nice. It was a good size, you could walk everywhere in about 30 minutes. It is probably the size of one city block, and the pedestrian walkway takes the shape of a "t" and one of the exits/entrances leads to a shopping street. I was there during the night and

the streets are very crowded and full with people. there're always having some kind of show, at least every time I go. the food are not Chinese, much more like faked-Japanese-flavored Chinese, through those were not expensive.

Nankinmachi, 神户南京盯 as it is known in Chinese. Close proximity to Meriken Park, Kobe Harborland. Lots of tourists stop by for a quick snack or fast meal before moving out to the next attraction. Being the Chinatown in Kobe, most of the stores here sell Chinese style snack/foods

This one is a neat little area covering a few blocks with the usual shops, restaurants and food stalls. Some of the street food is quite good. Didn't get to try the restaurants this trip. The slightly annoying part of the experience is the continual come-ons to go into a

It's a short walk, with a lot of shopkeepers touting their wares, Chinese delicacies and a bit of fusion foods. The interior of the shops reminds one of the generic contemporary Chinese taverns one can see in places like China or Taiwan, which are infused with some sense of
It is a right place to find chinese cuisine in Kobe. This is the only chinatown in Japan beside in Yokohama. So, its a must visit place when you are in Kobe

Must drop by to eat the kobe beef! and have a pint of beer! There are lots of street food, Ramen , Dumplings , Kobe beef , fried food and many more. However , not much place for you to sit to enjoy the food. There is also few Chinese restaurant in here .
Small China Town middle in Kobe at the Motomachi station. Try the snacks when you strolling by. Have a snack of Kobe beef with beer.

Nothing special except for lots of Chinese restaurants. Additionally, you can do some shopping too. Restaurants are of a wide variety and lots of food to choose from. However, this is a popular area among lots of people and a good experience to visit at least ones.
Lot of Chinese street food. It's like any other China Town. The food varied and some places was really good. Try Kobe beef burger and steak a must!!

Kobe Chinatown was next to the hotel where we were staying one of the best places to visit see learn and eat great types of Chinese and Japanese cuisine, visit during the day or night great place to do small type shopping etc

Was a bit disappointed visiting the place. The food stalls were repetitive and certainly did not look appealing. Didn't really eat much during my visit there, headed back to Osaka for food instead. But again a visit to Kobe without visit Chinatown is bit funny.

China town is a buzzing area in Kobe. Yet full of food stores and tiny restaurants. I didn't like it as much as the china towns in other cities or countries but it is worth visiting. I was not expecting so many food parlours. The smell can be overwhelming.

If you like getting lost in crowds and looking at products that you usually throw out after a year - this is the place for you. Colourful, loud, and very busy. Visit in the morning to avoid being overwhelmed. Endless shops and amusing displays of "one man's junk".

We went in the evening, so the lanterns were on and the whole area looked very festive. Many of the vendors were closing up at around 7pm. Plus lets of hawkers for restaurants etc. which we did not like.
Small, not authentic, and the worst food you'll find in japan. This area basically consists of some overpriced 'chinese' restaurants, and souvenir shops. Not worth visiting.

Kobe Chinatown is a street that is small, touristy but is quaint and delightful, however it is an area that restauranteur's beckon every visitor to come into their establishment. Painful at times but it's not threatening. Not worth the overall hassle though as there's not much

On a quiet Sunday afternoon, this area was crowded with students, local Japanese and tourists. The area spans a four way intersection. Local street vendors hawking their wares, mostly food. I was drawn to a long line of people waiting to eat or order steamed Chinese dumplings

I did not believe all the negative reviews I had read abiut china town in Kobe and had to see for myself. Since I lived close by I just had to take a look. It is located one street down from Motomachi station and can be entered through Motomachi shopping street. It is just like
This is a tad overhyped as it is nothing more than a street selling Chinese food in Kobe. It is also very small and does not give me the kind of feeling that I was in Chinatown.

Looks like a Hollywood version of China. Shanghai is only two hours away, if you want a taste, take a plane. Here everything is a bit too new, too clean, too sanitized, too "Japanese" to look like China for real. But if you want to take picture like in an Hollywood made up

Arrived in Kobe and went down at sunnomiya station. Great covered walk which we took to go to Chinatown which was a bit disappointing as being small area with restaurants with limited choices. I think you can have more fun around the station
Chinatown is much smaller than the one in Yokohoma. However the food stall and restaurants were more genuine tasty and reasonably priced

Hustle n bussle even during the day.. food every where. From Chinese to Turkish and kobe beef offerings. We sat down and ate because we were hot and tiered but if you can hade it. Walk around a try everything that takes your fancy. Around china town there are some cool shops and

Takd the subway and get off at motomachi station. Walk around through motomachi shooping strret and you can find china town not too far from there. I was able to travel to yokohama china town and was more attractive than kobe. There was nothing to do in this area just take a
A couple of streets with lots of little restaurants and touristy stuff. We were looking for more "classy" things, so not forus as we expected "more" to see.

Im chinese so its always interesting finding out what the food is like at chinese places. Stalls around were yum. We ducked into a random restaurant. Full of msg and not very good. Seafood wasnt fresh which is unforgiveable in a port city! I was doing a short visit, should
We were very tempted by all the food on offer - me in particular by the animal-shaped buns - but we had just checked in to our cruise ship so we passed up. Loved the gateways.
Nankinmachi (Chinatown) in Kobe is not as big as that of Yokohama, but interesting one. As I visited there just before the Chinese new year, I could enjoy a festive ambiance of the town.
A neat area tucked away in Kobe. A few stores to shop for trinkets and different types of Chinese and Kobe beef restaurants. The owl Cafe "BiBi & GeorGe" in this area was a fun and unique experience.

Not the biggest China town we've visited. Full of restaurants selling there stuff on stalls outside in the street all selling much the same kind of food. Not too many souvenir shops. Didn't spend too much time here.
We were excited to explore china town however not much is open before 11am! It's worth a visit as there is plenty of food outlets, tourist trinkets and traditional goods to buy

China Town, Kobe, is the perfect place to go to feast your curiosity for Asia. There are a myriad of Food Hawkers and restaurants, plus many souvenir shops. All of which could be had on a tight budget.

We have visited this China Town early in the morning on 30 May and found that most of the shops there were not yet opened for business. Anyway, most of the shops there were eating houses selling Chinese food and Kobe Beef. The place was clean and decorations in typical Chinese
China town in Kobe is quite small. But you still get some unique food or snack, or experience you don't usually get in Japan.

A change from the Japanese scene. Lots of hawkers food sold on roadside. We bought a few tempting snacks on the way but were disappointed as we are Malaysian chinese we found the taste very different. Anyway its a good tourist spot. The Loop bus will take you there.
Great atmosphere and colours but far too busy. Absolutely full of school-children. Prices were expensive so bargains were few. The architecture and details were worth the visit.

It is unlikely you will miss this place, as you will be greeted with a large Chinese gate at the entrance. Like any typical Chinatown in a modern city, there are the familiar Chinese architecture, temple, buildings along the street. Chinatown is all about food, food and food.

This area is full of delicious Chinese food like various kinds of dumplings, grilled Beijing duck, steamed yeast buns with minced pork filling, and Chinese sweets. I liked fried sesami dango with bean paste. You can enjoy getting them from the stalls and eating them on the
An opportunity to lunch here having Kobe beef. We enjoyed the preparation very much. Good strolling thru Chinatown lots of Chinese Restaurants around.

I walked through chinatown on my way to harbourland. It is quite a big area and lots of food. Most people there speak both japanese and chinese. Good to spend an hour wandering through if you have nothing else to do. The street for chinatown is parallel to the shopping street

It is about maybe less than 10 mins walk from the Motomachi station. When we arrived at 6pm, the place very crowded. If you want delicious food, follow the mass of people and they are definitely willing to queue for good food.

Lots of vendors hawking their goods. But it felt like my old Chinatown in Hawaii. I liked the stone statues of the zodiac though. It was a fast visit.

We had arrived earlier in the day but thought we would visit Chinatown at night as we imagined the atmosphere would be nice. It was only around 7:30pm but almost everything was closed and there were no people around at all. Disappointed as we had been recommended to visit here

it was so starange to find this famous china town in Japan the place was so intersting with so many china things which unusual available everywhere thoughout Japan recommended to be visited

Must visit while Kobe for people who loves to eat. Try nikumanju, its so tasty. Many people lined up to that one store (I didn't the name). Kobe beef is a little pricey, but its delicious and flavorful. I also try some noodles. Overall, I was so full when we left the place. Its

Colorful and genuine, lots of eaterier in and out, central, recommended in the evening. Except for some decoration it feels more Japanese than Chinese, a fair blend in this case.

Not to be missed .. the best range of economically priced souvenirs in Tokyo. Vibrant market stall with a variety of goods at great prices ... we wished we had come earlier in our trip. Not far from (across the river) the Tokyo Skytree. The temple and shrines are beautiful and

A place to look and see.. Restaurants are over priced.. Take some photo is good enough for me as we went in a group.. Some shop serves economical price food, but good grades are over priced!
Cheek by jowl Chinese restaurants along with plenty of street food options. Visited in the daytime but I'm guessing the area is more impressive at night. Would not make a trip here top of my list.

This is a food streets where they sell most Chinese Food and Kobe Beef.. feedback from my tourmates the kobe beef is very juicy
Caught the loop bus to go Kiosk almost selling the same stuff Restaurant are the same People more polite than real China We just stay for 20 mins and go back to Sannomiya station
there's so much stall snack to try, cheap price, i had try good dumpling there, more delicious than ohsko. really recommend for all of u to come there.

We dropped by this place after our kobe beef lunch. This is basically a food street with lots of stalls offering the same kinds of food. Thia place can be visited if you have free time but certainly not a must.

wandered through here & enjoyed the atmosphere & the location.........the food looked authentic & well priced ........

I love to going around here, it sell so many kind of item, and food. Especially the Kobe beef, make sure you don't miss to try the kobe beef in here, also the Kobe Beef Baozi (bao), some said that the taste were greate. Sadly i miss to try that. The price in here also not so

Nothing much more than a little Chinise architecture and street vendors trying to get you to come into their stores. We had a few 300¥ beers with was nice and took some pictures with the Chinise zodiacs and went on our marry way.
Lots of food and Chinese architecture. Good to walk around and dusk before heading to the port to see the lights on the water.

Our cruise ship docked at Kobe for a day. The shuttle bus took us downtown and dropped us off right at the City Loop’s bus stop #16. Right across the stop is China Town, so we went over there to join the other tourists. This street is very colourful and should be called "Food

A nice interesting 2 block stretch of Chinese food stalls, restaurants, souvenir shops marked by Chinese gates. Lots of good looking food to try out. A short 15 minute walk from Sannomiya Station. A little longer walk if you gawk at other sites along the way. Motomachi

Street food paradise. Come hungry. There were some shops that had lines outside. You buy from the stands and walk and eat or take out. There are also restaurants.

It was enjoyable to walk up and down the Chinatown street, looking to choose a restaurant from one of the many there. The Chinese decorations are very colourful and the atmosphere is great. We chose a very nice place and had a great dinner there. Worth a look and a bite if

Travellers - both domestic and international - flock to this busy, colourful are that pulses with life at any hour of the day. There are so many good restaurants that it is difficult to make a choice.

Worth checking out if happen to be nearby. I found it to be a bit small compared to the other Chinatowns that I'm used to. Colorful with some interesting places to eat.

It is not necessarily a Chinatown. Actually, it is more like a collection of Chinese Restaurants in a Japanese street with lots of Chinese decorations. Anyway, the food was pretty nice. So, If you would like to have some Chinese food you can stop by.

Red and golden color covered street in Kobe. We stayed in Okura Kobe hotel, we walked from hotel to China town and continued to motomachi shopping street and reached to Sogo department store of Sannomiya station. It's good distance to enjoy this area. Nankinmachi street is full

Didn't like how narrow the streets were because it was very crowded. I loved how colorful it was, and how many different shops there were to browse in.

This is essentially an area for food although I would hesitate to say that it is very Chinese. We did end up eating in one of the restaurants and the food tasted great. Walking down the street was a very interesting experience.

A Chinese street where you can find a lot of the Chinese cuisines but with some Japanese building. A good walk n may be shop(I din really have time shop). They sell Kobe beef too and the price is quite reasonable which my friend doubt is it the real stuff.
It was a amazing experience when I walk on the street where u can feel like in china or hing kong. Strongly advice to visit here.

From outward appearance, this little street and square appears authentically Chinese, but after closer inspection tourists will find that the food in restaurants are far removed from the original Chinese dishes and the staff in shops and restaurants rarely speak any Chinese.

Nice place to shop and a place to eat. One tip though, if you have tried the Kobe beef, do 'not' try the Chinese style of Kobe beef. Not recommended. Maybe a matter of personal taste, but I prefer the Japanese style Kobe beef. Ate at a Chinese restaurant there once for a change.

This is not your typical Chinatown. The street was quite clean with lots of restaurants and vendors selling the same thing along the street. I thought it was expensive for a meal here.
A very small Chinatown. Quite typical and traditional and selling also the same things like the bun and dumplings.

Just a so-so experience. It is just like a common Chinatown. Many options for Chinese food - not very expensive but not delicious either. Many Chinese stuffs sold here also. Not too much to do here.

chinatowns are the same every where in the world. nothing special here either. snooze fest. best to miss. youre in japan! eat japanese food, buy local stuff. if u want chinese stuff, visit china.

Wasn't disappointed after seeking out the Chinatown area. Had a delicious set lunch in one of the many restaurants. The area is much the same as Chinatowns all over the world. Lots of colour and smells of great food. Took some nice photos here.

Located just to the south of the Santica Shopping Mall, Chinatown is very picturesque and a nice place to take photos. I have been there on previous travels to Japan. Many places to eat, but I have no recommendations. After awhile, it just seems to be another tourist trap.

Been passing trough Kobe's China town here, it's relatively small but a nice walk with a nice flair. If you walk with family and are not on a big shopping spree it only takes 20minutes, than you seen it all - from outside.

i was really impressed on the cleanliness. I've been to quite a few China Town in the world, but the one in Kobe was just different. a lot of food stuff from south east asia were available here.

easy to find, its next to the nakamise. Lots of restaurants to chose from.
Good for eating food and just strolling through. Not very big. You only need 30 mins to walk explore and eat some street food.

text.wiki:
Kōbe Ōji Zoo (神戸市立王子動物園, Kōbe-shiritsu Ōji Dōbutsuen), or simply Kobe Zoo or Ōji Zoo (王子動物園), is a municipal zoo in Kobe, Japan.


== Attractions ==

Panda House (パンダ館)
Giant pandas since 2000.Zoological Science Center (動物科学資料館)
An indoor educational center featuring skeletal specimens and a reading room.Big Cats Circle (円形猛獣舎)
tigers, lions, leopards, snow leopards, and jaguars.Polar Bear House (ホッキョクグマ舎)
Aboveground and underwater viewing areasAnimals' Land & Children's Zoo (動物とこどもの国)
red pandas, otters, koalas and some farmyard animals.A small amusement park (遊園地)
Rides and games for children, includes a Ferris wheel and chair swing ride.The E.H. Hunter House (旧ハンター住宅)
The former residence of the founder of Osaka Iron Works, Edward Hazlett Hunter. An elaborate example of a 19th-century ijinkan (異人館, "foreign home"), it is at the northeast corner the zoo (hence not accessible outside zoo hours). The interior – with roped-off period furniture – is only open a few months each year. It was designated an Important Cultural Property by both the prefecture and the nation.Animals in other sections include giraffes, zebras, kangaroos, ostriches, flamingos, hippos, some species of apes, crocodiles, bobcats, sea lions, snow owls, and elephants.


== Surrounding ==
Technically the zoo is within Ōji Park (王子公園, Ōji Kōen), but the zoo is enclosed and has admission fees. Surrounding the zoo are the various parts of a sports complex. To the zoo's northwest is the Ōji Sports Center (王子スポーツセンター, Ōji Supōtsu Sentā). To the northeast are some tennis courts; to the east is Ōji Stadium; to the southwest is the Museum of Literature.


== References ==


== External links ==

text.wiki:
Ikuta Shrine (生田神社, Ikuta-jinja) is a Shinto shrine in the Chūō Ward of Kobe, Japan, and is possibly among the oldest shrines in the country.


== History ==
According to Nihon Shoki, it was founded by the Empress Jingū at the beginning of the 3rd century AD to enshrine the kami Wakahirume. It was one of three shrines established at this time; the others are Hirota Shrine, dedicated to Amaterasu, and Nagata Shrine, dedicated to Kotoshiro-nushi (also known as Ebisu).
During the Genpei War, parts of the Battle of Ichi-no-Tani took place in and around this shrine, and are commemorated by markers in the Ikuta forest behind the shrine. The shrine's land was much larger back then, before the city of Kobe was built around it. Thus, the precise locations of skirmishes or events can no longer be commemorated on shrine land.


== Festivals and events ==
Today, two Noh plays, Ebira and Ikuta Atsumori, which retell aspects of the Genpei War, are performed near the Ikuta Shrine on a regular basis. They are performed every year at Ikuta's Autumn Festival (秋祭り, Akimatsuri).


== See also ==
List of Shinto shrines
Twenty-Two Shrines
Modern system of ranked Shinto Shrines


== References ==
生田神社, (Japanese)


== External links ==
Official website (in Japanese)

text.wiki:
The gardens of Sōraku-en (相楽園) are in Chūō-ku, Kobe, Japan. Formerly attached to the Taishō-era residence of Kodera Yasujirō, ownership passed to the city of Kobe in 1941. Since then they have been open to the public. Most of the former residence was destroyed in the Pacific War; the stables of 1907 survived and have been designated an Important Cultural Property.It is one of the few historical Japanese gardens that exists within Kobe city.  It adopts a "chisen kaiyu shiki (池泉回遊式)”, style which is a style of garden that features a path around a pond. The giant camphor tree standing inside the garden is considered one of the most iconic elements of the site. This tree is known to have been there before the original residence of Kodera Yasujirō was built.In the gardens are the former Hassam Residence, built by the English architect Alexander Nelson Hansell in 1902 and relocated to its current site in 1963 (ICP); an Edo-period building shaped like a boathouse, dating from 1682-1704 (ICP); a tea house; and a stroll garden.In 2006 Sōraku-en was registered as a Place of Scenic Beauty. The gardens take their name from a passage of the I Ching.
